Fig. 1 Space-time ethylene yield for unmodified and Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts during ODE reaction in the “standard” mixture with C2H6/O2 = 1/1 at 400 °C. Data are presented for each catalyst before and after treatment with «reducing» mixture (C2H6/O2 = 3/1) at 460 °C. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Curve-fitted in situ Nb3d spectra for Bi-doped MoVNbTeO catalysts under ODE conditions (C2H6/O2 = 1/1, T = 400 °C). All spectra normalized to the equal Mo amount. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Curve-fitted (a,b) Mo3d and (c,d) V2p spectra for unmodified MoVNbTeO catalyst (a,c) under UHV and (b,d) C2H6 + O2 conditions. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 The contribution of Mo6+ and V5+ species on the surface of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts during NAP-XPS study: (a) Bi/Mo = 0 , (b) Bi/Mo = 0.0075 , (c) Bi/Mo = 0.025 . The C2H6/O2 ratio was varied from 1/1 to 10/1 at 400 or 460 °C. The data labeled as «UHV RT» correspond to spectra measured under ultra-high vacuum (˜10–9 mbar) at room temperature. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Surface Te content in terms of Te/(Mo + V) ratio under different reaction conditions for unmodified and Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 In situ X-ray patterns of MoVNbTeO catalysts obtained during the heating in 8% C2H6/He flow: (a) Bi/Mo = 0 , (b) Bi/Mo = 0.0075 . Unmarked reflections correspond to M1 phase, while the peaks from M2 phase are marked with asterisks. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Phase composition for (a) unmodified and (b) Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts during heating in 8% C2H6/He flow. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The change in a, b, and c cell parameters for M1 phase within Bi/Mo = 0 and Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalysts during heating in 8% C2H6/He flow. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) X-ray absorption spectra on Bi L3-edge for Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalysts and reference samples α-Bi2O3 and α-Bi2Mo3O12; (b) corresponding FTs of EXAFS oscillations. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 The scheme of Bi localization within the extended six-membered channel of the M1 structure. Oxygen atoms are small balls designated by red color; Nb (green) and Bi (pink) atoms are big marked balls; Mo atoms (blue) are big unmarked balls. Segments of black color correspond to partial occupation of Mo position by V atoms(For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article). Lavrentieva 5 Novosibirsk 630090 Russia Graphical abstract This work presents the investigation of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODE) using the combination of NAP-XPS, in situ XRD and XANES/EXAFS techniques. It was found that introduction of Bi improves the tolerance of catalysts toward severe reaction conditions (high temperature and/or enhanced ethane/oxygen ratio) resulting in a significant decrease in the degree of deactivation. In accordance with NAP-XPS data, the surface/subsurface Te concentration was maintained for Bi-containing MoVNbTeO catalysts even after treatment with a reducing reaction mixture (C2H6/O2 >3) at temperatures up to 460 °C. In the case of the unmodified catalyst, such treatment resulted in the surface/subsurface depletion of Te due to the reduction into the Te° state followed by its sublimation into the gas phase. The incorporation of Bi within extended six-membered channels of the M1 structure was suggested based on XANES/EXAFS data. Such incorporation probably influences the mobility of Te within channels, resulting in the limitation of Te diffusion from the particle bulk to the surface. The improved tolerance of catalytically active M1 phase toward severe reaction conditions was confirmed by in situ XRD data during heating in a mixture of 8 wt % C2H6/He. Keywords MoVNbTe M1 phase NAP-XPS Oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane ODE In situ Catalyst modification EXAFS Bismuth Six-membered channel Tellurium Slurry method 1 Introduction The mixed oxides MoVNbTe(Sb)O are unique catalytic systems for the partial oxidation of C2–C4 hydrocarbons, including oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODE) [1], selective oxidation of propane/propylene [2,3] and ammoxidation [4,5]. Note that the ODE process is considered as potentially effective alternative approach for the production of ethylene – an important monomer in the chemical industry [6]. The key structural units in the composition of MoVNbTe(Sb)O catalysts are the orthorhombic M1 and pseudo-hexagonal M2 phases [7,8]. The catalytic activity of MoVNbTe(Sb)O oxides in partial oxidation of ethane/propane is caused mainly by the presence of the orthorhombic M1 phase, as M2 is not able to activate the CH bond in alkanes [2,9–11]. The preparation of a phase-pure M1 system without M2 admixture can be performed using hydrothermal synthesis [12] or as result of post-treatment with H2O2 [2,13]. The most effective MoVNbTeO catalyst for ODE process provides an ethane conversion of 88–90% with the ethylene selectivity of 81–87% resulting in an ethylene yield close to 72–76% [14]. Along with catalytic activity, stable operation under real conditions is one of the most important characteristics necessary for the commercialization of developed catalysts. However, papers devoted to the investigation of the stability/deactivation of MoVNbTeO catalysts are not numerous and are ambiguous. On one hand, the M1 MoVNbTeO system is described as an extremely stable catalyst [15–17]. On the other, even a short-time (˜0.5 h) treatment of such a catalyst with a reducing reaction mixture (C2H6/O2 = 3/1) at 400 °C results in deactivation in terms of ethane conversion and ethylene selectivity [18]. Chu et al. showed that not only reaction conditions but also Te content can influence on the stability of phase-pure M1 MoVNbTeO [19]. A catalyst with high Te content (Tе/Mо = 0.23) demonstrated a monotonic decrease in ethane conversion during interaction with a mixture of C2H6/O2/He = 3/2/5 at 420 °C A catalyst with low Te content (Tе/Mо = 0.07–0.10) was found to be deactivated at enhanced temperature (up to 460 °C) or after increase in O2 concentration in the reaction mixture. The thermal stability of a MoVNbTeO catalyst with composition of Mo/V/Nb/Te = 1/0.24/0.18/0.24 was studied [20]. It was established that this catalyst deactivates in the mixture C2H6/O2/N2 = 9/7/84 at temperatures ≥500 °C. The majority of researchers have a common point of view that deactivation of MoVNbTeO catalysts under ODE conditions is caused by the reduction of tellurium into Te° species [18–20]. Such species block active sites on the surface or escape the catalyst, resulting in M1 decomposition with the formation of Mо5O14− or MоO2-like structures. It was expected that the replacement of Te within the M1 structure by less volatile Sb could improve the catalyst stability under reaction conditions [2]. However, the introduction of Sb resulted in an evident decrease in activity in alkane oxidation [21]. Moreover, no reliable data concerning the influence of Sb on the stability of M1-based catalysts was obtained. The modification or doping of MoVNbTeO oxide by small amounts of various elements with the preservation of M1 structure is the well-known approach to improve its properties. For example, the modification by Bi assists the retention of Te within the M1 phase, providing tolerance of the catalyst toward strongly reducing treatments [22]. The current work continues the investigation of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts for ODE. The purpose of work was to establish the influence of introduced Bi on the surface dynamics (state and composition) and structural features of MoVNbTeO catalysts under reducing reaction conditions. The application of NAP-XPS and in situ XRD methods provided the reliable experimental data about surface and bulk transformations, respectively. 2 Experimental part 2.1 Synthesis Catalysts with the calculated cationic molar composition Mo1.0V0.3Te0.23Nb0.12Bi0–0.25Oх were synthesized by a slurry method [23–25]. Synthesis steps included mixing of aqueous solutions of the starting reagents, drying of the resulting gel-like precursor in B-290 (Buchi, Switzerland) laboratory spray drier at 220 °C, and a subsequent stepwise heat treatment of the dry precursor in ﬂowing helium at 550 °C with intermediate heat treatment in ﬂowing air at 310 °C. Ammonium molybdate (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O (NevaReactiv, Russia), ammonium metavanadate NH4VO3 (Reakhim, Russia), telluric acid H6TeO6 (Aldrich, USA), bismuth nitrate Bi(NO3)3∙5H2O (Vekton, Russia), and niobium oxalate were used as the starting sources. Niobium oxalate was prepared by the reported approach [25,26]. The content of main components in the reagents was above 99%. Synthesized catalysts, depending on amount of introduced Bi, were designated as Bi/Mo = 0 (unmodified catalyst), Bi/Mo = 0.004, Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and Bi/Mo = 0.025 pointing the molar ratio of introduced Bi and Mo. The bulk chemical composition of prepared catalysts was found using an ISP OPTIMA 4300DV (Perkin Elmer, USA) atomic emission spectrophotometer (AES). The sample of α-Bi2Mo3O12 as reference for EXAFS/XANES study was prepared by mixing ammonium molybdate and bismuth nitrate solutions followed by evaporation, drying at 120 °C and air-calcination at 500 °C for 5 h. Another reference sample, α-Bi2O3, was obtained commercially (Reakhim, Russia). 2.2 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy In situ XPS was performed using the laboratory NAP-XPS system (SPECS Surface Nano Analysis, GmbH Germany). The special “chamber-in-chamber” design allowed in situ XPS studies at pressures ranging from 10−9 mbar up to 20 mbar, and temperatures ranging from 200 K to 773 K. Detailed description of such a system can be found in literature [27,28]. Experiments were performed using monochromatic Al Kα X-ray radiation. Powder catalysts were pressed into stainless steel wire meshes attached to the sample holder by spot welding. No charging effects were observed during spectrum acquisition (the position of Eb(C1s) was close to ˜284.8 eV). The sample was heated conductively by electron bombardment of the rear of the sample holder mounted on an NAP manipulator. The temperature was monitored by a K-type thermocouple welded near the mesh and the pressed sample. Spectrum measurements were performed under ultra-high vacuum (UHV, ˜10–9 mbar) or under reaction (C2H6 + O2, P˜1 mbar) conditions. In the case of NAP experiments, the sample was first maintained under reaction conditions for 30–40 min after change in reaction temperature or C2H6/O2 ratio. The working pressure in the NAP cell was ˜2.5 mbar during reaction exposure and reduced to 1 mbar during spectrum measurements keeping the same C2H6/O2 ratio. Processing of spectral data was performed using XPS-Calc software, which has been applied for various catalytic systems [29–31]. The procedure of curve-fitting was performed using an approximation based on a combination of the Gaussian and Lorentzian functions with the subtraction of Shirley-type background. The calculation of XPS surface composition is described in the Supplementary material section. 2.3 X-ray diffraction XRD data were measured using CuKα radiation with a D8 (Bruker, Germany) diffractometer focusing θ-θ geometry. A LynxEye (Bruker, Germany) detector was applied for data acquisition, and an XRK900 reaction chamber (Anton Paar GmbH, Austria) was used for in situ measurements. The samples were heated in 8 vol % C2H6 in He from 400 to 580 °C with steps of 20 °C and a heating rate of 12°/min. The gas flow rate was ca.16 ml/min. The XRD pattern was measured at each temperature step over an angular range of 2θ = 5–50° at a 0.05° step and acquisition time of 1 s. Phase analysis, refinement of unit cell parameters and the quantitative content calculations were performed by the full profile modeling of X-ray patterns by the Rietveld method. The calculations were made using the TOPAS software package [32], while structural parameters were taken from the literature [7] and ICSD database [33]. The fundamental parameter approach and an external standard material (silicon powder) were used to calculate the instrumental contribution to the line broadening. 2.4 Catalyst testing Exposure of the synthesized catalysts under the ODE conditions was carried out in a flow setup at atmospheric pressure with on-line chromatographic analysis of the reaction mixture. A tubular glass reactor (Øout = 10 mm) was equipped with a coaxially located thermocouple pocket (Øout = 5 mm). Two reaction mixture compositions were used: "standard" with molar ratio C2H6/O2/N2 = 1/1/8 and "reducing" with molar ratio C2H6/O2/N2 = 3/1/6. Catalysts were exposed to the "standard" mixture from 400 to 480 °C with stepwise increments of 10 or 20 °C. The time of exposure at each temperature was about 3–3.5 h; the total time in the "standard” mixture was 25 h. Then, catalysts were exposed under "reducing" conditions at 460 °C for 3 h followed by a control test in the "standard" reaction mixture at 400 °C. Contact time was 2.7 s for all catalysts. To compare the properties of the catalysts exposed to “standard” and “reducing” mixtures, for the purpose of estimating the catalyst stability, we used the specific space-time yield of ethylene (SSTY). The SSTY value was calculated as follows: (1) S S T Y = U ∙ φ ∙ X ∙ S ∙ n ∙ M r m ∙ ω , i n g ( C 2 H 4 ) / ( g M 1 ∙ h ) where U – reaction mixture flow (cm3/h), φ – ethane volume concentration (% vol.), X – ethane conversion (%), S – ethylene selectivity (%), n – number of gas moles per 1 cm3 at 25 °C, Mr – ethylene molecular weight (g/mol), m – catalyst weight (g), ω – the contribution of M1 phase (% wt.) from XRD data. 2.5 XANES/EXAFS The measurement of X-ray absorption spectra at the Bi L3-edge were performed at the Structural Materials Science beamline at the Kurchatov Synchrotron Radiation Source (National Research Center “Kurchatov Institute”, Moscow, Russia) [34]. The source was a 2.5 GeV electron storage ring with beam current from 50 to 120 mA. X-ray absorption of catalyst was acquired in the fluorescence yield mode using an avalanche silicon diode (FMB Oxford, UK). X-ray absorption of reference samples ( α-Bi2O3 and α-Bi2Mo3O12 ) were measured in the transmission mode. Finely ground powder samples were mounted on the surface of kapton tape. The X-ray absorption spectrum of metallic Bi foil was acquired simultaneously with the measurement of each sample. The obtained data was analyzed using IFEFFIT software [35]. The threshold ionization energy (E0) was chosen by using the derivative first maximum for absorption edge. The E0 value was varied to reach a more precise curve fit. The Fourier transformation of EXAFS oscillations was carried out in the k-range of 3.01–14 Å−1. The fitting was performed in the r-range of 1.2–4.5 Å with k and k2-weight. 3 Results The bulk element concentrations defined by AES corresponded to calculated composition for all synthesized catalysts (see Table S1, Supporting information). Only one exception related to a decreased Te content was caused by Te reduction followed by Te° sublimation during high-temperature heating [22,23,36]. The specific surface area for all catalysts was close to 5–6 m2/g. The content of M1 and M2 phases in the as-prepared catalysts was calculated from XRD data. The introduction of Bi resulted in a drop of M1 content from 97 to 70–73 wt %, balanced by the growth of M2 contribution (Table S1). The crystallinity degree of all Bi-modified samples was ca. 80% regardless of the Bi concentration. 3.1 Catalyst stability The correlation has been previously established between ODE reaction rate and M1 content for unmodified [9], and for Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts [22]. Therefore, the space-time yield (STY) of ethylene was normalized to M1 phase content (so-called specific space-time yield – SSTY). The reaction exposure during heating to 480 °C did not cause any changes in quantitative and qualitative phase composition of the studied catalysts (see Section 3.3 . below). Fig. 1 presents the STTY values obtained at 400 °C in the “standard” mixture (with molar ratio C2H6/O2/N2 = 1/1/8) before and after treatment in the “reducing” mixture (with molar ratio C2H6/O2/N2 = 3/1/6) at 460 °C. The reaction temperature of 460 °C was found to be optimal for the investigation of MoVNbTeO deactivation. Note that the increase in reaction temperature to 480 °C using the “standard” reaction mixture resulted in only a negligible change in SSTY value measured after cooling to 400 °C, indicating the stable operation of the studied MoVNbTeO catalysts (see Fig. S1, Supporting Information). Fig. 1 shows that the modification of MoVNbTeO oxides by Bi enhanced the STY value per gram of active M1 phase. The SSTY value was close to ˜0.12 g ((C2H4)/(g(M1)∙h) regardless of the amount of introduced Bi. The treatment of unmodified catalyst Bi/Mo = 0 with the “reducing” mixture at 460 °C resulted in a significant drop in activity measured in the “standard” mixture. The specific steady-state ethylene yield decreased by 42% in comparison to the initial value, indicating the evident deactivation of the unmodified catalyst. The introduction of small amount of Bi ( Bi/Mo = 0.004 catalyst) was not enough to prevent deactivation under “reducing” conditions (SSTY drop of ˜43%). The enhanced tolerance toward “reducing” conditions was reached when the amount of introduced Bi was in the Bi/Mo range of 0.0075–0.025. In such cases, the decrease in SSTY value after “reducing” treatment was no more than 24%. 3.2 Near ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Mixed MoVNbTeO oxides with various Bi contents (catalysts Bi/Mo = 0 , Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and Bi/Mo = 0.025 ) were studied using NAP-XPS immediately during heating in C2H6 + O2 mixture. The surface state and surface composition of the catalysts were defined under UHV (˜10–9 mbar) and reaction (up to 2.5 mbar) conditions. The reaction temperature was varied from 400 to 460 °C, while the C2H6/O2 ratio was changed from 1 to 10. High ethane concentration was applied in the reaction mixture to simulate “reducing” treatment in a flow-bed reactor. For all studied catalysts, the analysis of Nb3d region revealed the presence of two components with binding energy (Eb) of the Nb3d5/2 peak close to ˜206.7 (Nb-1) and 207.3 eV (Nb-2). Fig. 2 presents the curve-fitting of in situ Nb3d spectra for Bi-modified catalysts. These spectra were acquired at 400 °C in the C2H6/O2 = 1/1 mixture. The shape, position and relative intensity of Nb3d spectra were the same during changes in reaction conditions, such as temperature or C2H6/O2 ratio (Fig. S2). The Eb(Nb3d5/2) value close to ˜207 eV corresponds to Nb5+ state [37]. In the case of oxidized Nb within Mo5O14- or M1-type structures, the Eb(Nb3d5/2) is near ˜206.8 eV [38,39], while the position of the Nb3d5/2 peak for Nb2O5 oxide varies in the range from 207.2 to 207.5 eV [40,41]. It was shown that incorporation of Nb in the center of the pentagonal bipyramid within the M1 structure occurs during high-temperature heating above 400 °C as a result of interaction between NbOx and Mо-V-Te species [42]. Based on this data, the Nb-1 component was attributed to Nb5+ ions within the MoVNbTeO oxide structure (mainly M1), while the Nb-2 component corresponded to unreacted NbOx species. Comparing Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and Bi/Mo = 0.025 catalysts, the growth in both Nb-1/Mo and Nb-2/Mo ratios was observed along with the increase in Bi content. Note that both catalysts contained ˜25–30 wt % of M2 phase (Table S1). Since Nb is not key structural element for formation of the M2 structure [2,43], the M1 particles predominately could be considered to be enriched by Nb. Simultaneously, the amount of residual NbOx species was increased. So, the modification of catalysts by Bi influences the interaction between NbOx and Mo–V–Te species, resulting in the redistribution of Nb within MoVNbTeO particles. Fig. 3 shows the example of Mo3d and V2p spectra obtained for the unmodified Bi/Mo = 0 catalyst under UHV and in situ ODE conditions. The Mo3d spectra were curve-fitted on two components with Еb(Mo3d5/2) values near ˜232.3 and ˜233 eV. Based on literature data these components were attributed to Mo5+ and Mо6+ states, respectively [42,44,45]. The combination of Mo5+ and Mо6+ states in MoVNbTeO oxides has been reliably determined [8,38]. The analysis of V2p spectra revealed the presence of two components with Еb(V2p3/2) values close to ˜516.3 and ˜517.2 eV. These were attributed to V4+ and V5+ species, respectively [15,46,47]. The Mo3d and V2p spectra measured during in situ experiments had similar shapes and positions regardless of reaction conditions (temperature or C2H6/O2 ratio). The dependence of the contribution of V5+ and Mo6+ species on reaction conditions is plotted in Fig. 4 . For all studied MoVNbTeO catalysts, the Mо6+ contribution was initially close to 44 ± 2% (in UHV), while it decreased to 37 ± 2% under C2H6 + O2 conditions. The change in reaction temperature from 400 to 460 °C and the variation in C2H6/O2 ratio from 1 to 10 did not cause additional Mo reduction, retaining the Mo5+ and Mо6+ concentrations. The slight fluctuation in Mо6+ concentration was within the error of quantitative XPS analysis. Obtained data concerning the dynamics of Mo6+ content is in a good agreement with the other results of MoVNbTeO characterization by in situ XPS under C3H8 + O2 conditions [47]. The V state at the surface of studied MoVNbTeO catalysts was almost unchanged during NAP-XPS study – the contribution from V5+ component close to 31 ± 2% was similar for all reaction conditions (Fig. 4). However, the average V state in the case of UHV was found to be more oxidized (the V5+ content near 38 ± 2%) by comparison with reaction conditions. Note that the predominant V4+ contribution at the surface of MoVNbTeO was previously observed at 420 °C during in situ XPS study using a C3H8 + O2 reaction mixture [46]. Therefore, the surface of Bi-modified and unmodified MoVNbTeO catalysts after treatment with C2H6 + O2 mixture at 400–460 °C underwent reduction resulting in the increase in V4+ and Mо5+ content. No systematic change of average V or Mo charge state was observed under various reaction conditions. The Bi and Te states at the surface of MoVNbTeO catalysts were analyzed using Bi4f and Te3d regions, respectively. Such spectral regions obtained during in situ experiments are presented in Fig. S3. The binding energy of the Bi4f7/2 peak was close to 159.2 eV for all studied catalysts regardless of experimental conditions (UHV or ODE) and corresponds to Bi3+ state [22,37,48]. Also, the position of the Te3d5/2 maximum near ˜576.4 eV did not change during various reaction exposures for all samples. The observed Eb(Te3d5/2) value, along with the small peak width (FWHM of 1.3 eV), indicated the presence of Te4+ species [38,49,50], while the appearance of other Te species at the surface of studied catalysts was not confirmed by NAP-XPS. Table S2 presents quantitative XPS data concerning element composition at the surface of as-prepared and treated MoVNbTeO catalysts during NAP-XPS. The relative quantities of V and Nb expressed as V/Mo and Nb/Mo ratios were not evidently changed for all catalysts when reaction conditions were varied. In comparison with bulk chemical composition, the surface of MoVNbTeO oxide was found to be depleted in V and enriched in Nb (Table S1). This is in agreement with literature data on M1-based MoVNbTeO systems prepared by a “slurry” method [51] or prepared by hydrothermal synthesis [52]. Note that the distribution of V and/or Mo in the M1 structure of MoVNbTeO particles depends on preparation procedure, chemical composition and reaction treatment [15,52–54]. The content of V at the surface (V/Mo) was close to ˜0.15 for all studied catalysts regardless of experimental conditions. The Nb concentration (Nb/Mo) was found to increase from ˜0.15 to ˜0.2 along with the growth of introduced amount of Bi and was not changed during the variation in reaction conditions. Sanfiz et al. also did not observe any change in surface concentration of V and Nb during propane oxidation at 350 °C based on in situ XPS data [39]. However, the surface enrichment in V could take place during prolonged testing (>10 h) in the presence of water vapor in the reaction mixture [15]. The initial Bi concentration measured in UHV corresponded to its bulk concentration (Tables S1 and S2). As the reaction conditions became more severe (increase in temperature and/or C2H6/O2 ratio), the Bi/Mo value at the surface was found to be slightly decreased relative to its initial value. The variation in reaction conditions resulted in a significant change in surface Te concentration (Table S2 and Fig. 5 ) without alteration in the charge state of Te detected by XPS (Fig. S4). The Te content was normalized using the contents of both V and Mo as the main structural elements. The contribution of Nb was not taken into account due to the variation in Nb/Mo concentration for different Bi-containing catalysts (Table S2). Reduced forms of Te such as Tе2+ and Tе° are characterized by Eb(Te3d5/2) values near ˜574 and ˜573 eV, respectively [18,21,45]. It is well-known that the Tе2+ state is very unstable [21], while elemental Te° is able to sublimate under pressure of ˜1 mbar at 300–350 °C [55]. Therefore, the detection of reduced Te species by in situ XPS is rather difficult. XPS detection of the Te4+ state does not rule out the formation of reduced Tе2+ and Tе° species during reaction exposure. Particularly, when the rate of Te° sublimation at 400–460 °C is higher than the rate of Te4+ reduction to the Te° state, elemental Te will not accumulate at the catalyst surface. Fig. 5 presents the comparison of surface Te concentration for unmodified and Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts during NAP-XPS. The initial value of Te/(Mo + V) for all studied catalysts was close to 0.20 ± 0.02, determined at 400 °C in the C2H6/O2 = 1/1 mixture. Along with reaction temperature increase to 460 °C, an increase in surface Te content was observed, especially for Bi-containing samples. In the case of the C2H6/O2 = 3/1 mixture at 460 °C, the Te/(Mo + V) value was found to be increased or unchanged for Bi-modified catalysts, while it was reduced for the unmodified MoVNbTeO sample. The initial surface of as-prepared MoVNbTeO catalysts is usually enriched in Te [51,52], in good agreement with the present work (Tables S1 and S2). In the case of the Te3d region, the XPS analysis depth estimated as λ (inelastic mean free path) using Al Kα radiation is near ˜1.8 nm. Therefore, data presented in Fig. 5 relates to the changes not only in the surface, but also the subsurface/bulk region. Under reaction conditions, the diffusion of Te from bulk to the surface followed by reduction and sublimation occurs [20]. Thus, the behavior of the Te/(Mo + V) parameter depending on reaction conditions can be explained by both mentioned processes, i.e. (1) diffusion from the bulk, and (2) sublimation from the surface. Note that the Te content at the surface of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO oxides under “reducing” conditions (C2H6/O2 = 3/1, 460 °C) was significantly higher than in case of unmodified Bi/Mo = 0 catalysts. Under more severe conditions (C2H6/O2 = 10/1, 460 °C) the enhanced Te concentration was found to be maintained for Bi-containing samples. The decrease in Te/(Mo + V) value relates to the reduction of Te4+ to Te° followed by its sublimation when the diffusion of Te from the bulk is limited. The observed difference in absolute Te/(Mo + V) value between Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and Bi/Mo = 0.025 catalysts is likely to be caused by the different Bi content and its distribution within MoVNbTeO particles. In particular, the high Bi content can be responsible for the limitation of Te diffusion from the bulk to the surface, resulting in lower Te/(Mo + V) value measured mainly for the surface/subsurface region. 3.3 In situ X-ray diffraction Based on results of catalytic measurements and NAP-XPS, the catalyst with Bi/Mo = 0.0075 was chosen for investigation using in situ XRD during heating in 8 vol % C2H6 in helium. Also, unmodified Bi/Mo = 0 catalyst was studied as a comparison sample. Fig. 6 presents corresponding in situ X-ray patterns. Note that both Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and Bi/Mo = 0 catalysts contain the combination of M1 and M2 phases but with different M1/M2 ratios (Table S1). Heating of MoVNbTeO catalysts to 580 °C in 8 vol % C2H6/He resulted in the complete destruction of M1 and M2 phases, accompanied by the appearance of X-ray reflections attributed to a monoclinic MoO2-type structure (PDF-2 #00-032-0671). The existence of MoO2-type structures containing V and Nb is known; for example, VxMo1-xO2 and NbxMo1-xO2 solid solutions [56,57]. The modification of MoVNbTeO oxide by Bi had an influence on the decomposition of M1 phase. Fig. 7 shows the quantitative phase composition of studied catalysts depending on reaction temperature in 8% C2H6/He flow. In the case of the unmodified sample, the evident structural changes started at T ≥ 520 °C only. In particular, the M1 contribution decreased to 31 wt % at 540 °C, while it completely disappeared at 560 °C. In the case of Bi-modified catalysts, the X-ray reflections of MoO2-type structure had already appeared at 480 °C, accompanied by a decrease in M2 content. The MoO2 contribution increased mainly at the cost of the M2 phase, while the change in M1 content was less than 10%. The evident destruction of the M1 phase only started at 560 °C, when the M2 structure was absent. Note that the M1 content for Bi-modified catalysts at 560 °C was near ˜40 wt %, while it was completely transformed into a MoO2-type structure at the same temperature in the case of unmodified Bi/Mo = 0 catalyst. Therefore, the modification of MoVNbTeO oxide by Bi resulted in enhanced thermal stability of the M1 phase under strongly reducing conditions (in 8% C2H6/He flow). The influence of M1 + M2 phase cooperation on catalytic properties is widely discussed in the literature [5,58]. One possible reason for such an effect is the participation of the M2 phase as a reservoir of Te for the active M1 phase under reaction conditions [2]. Since the M1 and M2 contributions were different for Bi/Mo = 0 and Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalysts, the influence of phase cooperation on thermal stability cannot be ruled out in the case of Bi-containing samples with enhanced M2 content. Additionally, the unmodified sample containing ˜20 wt % M2 phase (designated as Bi/Mo = 0 2nd) was investigated by in situ XRD during heating in 8% C2H6/He flow. For this sample, the destruction of the M1 phase started at a temperature of 480 °C, while it was complete at 500 °C with the formation of MoO2-type structure (Fig. S5). This indicates that the enhanced M2 phase content is not enough for stabilization of the M1 structure under strongly reducing conditions. Fig. 8 presents the dependence of M1 cell parameters on reaction temperature during heating of Bi/Mo = 0 and Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalysts in 8% C2H6/He flow. No evident change in these parameters was observed for both samples up to 480 °C, indicating the absence of any structural transformations within the M1 structure. The increase in a and b parameters occurred at temperature ≥500 °C for Bi/Mo = 0 catalyst, accompanied by a reduction in c parameter. In the case of Bi-containing samples, the increase in a and b parameters was only observed above 520 °C, relating to the start of M1 destruction (Fig. 7). At the same time, the c parameter was found to be unchanged over the full temperature range of M1 phase existence. In Fig. S6 the stacking of in situ X-ray patterns acquired at 400, 520 and 540 °C in 8% C2H6/He flow is presented for both studied samples. Previously, the significant increase in a and b cell parameters with the simultaneous decrease in c parameter was observed for orthorhombic M1 phase with the composition of Mo29V11O112 during reducing treatment [59]. Such behavior is explained as related to the removal of lattice oxygen and the change in charge states of V and Mo. In situ XRD allowed us to establish the increase in thermal stability of M1 phase under strongly reducing conditions, when Bi is introduced into the catalyst structure. In particular, the behavior of c cell parameter of the M1 structure depending on reaction temperature was significantly different for Bi-modified and unmodified catalysts (Fig. 8). Also, the dynamics of change in M1 crystal size was opposite for such samples (Fig. S7). 3.4 XANES/EXAFS spectroscopy Fig. 9 a presents the Bi L3-edge X-ray absorption spectra for Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and reference samples α-Bi2O3 and α-Bi2Mo3O12. The main difference between the spectra of Bi/Mo = 0.0075 and α-Bi2O3 is the additional B peak with a maximum near 13455 eV appearing for the Bi-modified catalyst. Such a peak, also observed for α-Bi2Mo3O12, is likely related to the appearance of Mo in the second and following coordination spheres of Bi. Fourier transforms (FTs) of EXAFS oscillations on Bi L3-edge are presented for all studied samples in Fig. 9b. The most intensive peak (near 1.6 Å) for FT module curves of all samples is characteristic of a Bi–O coordination sphere. A more complicated spectral structure is observed in the distance range from 2.6 to 3.5 Å and relates to Bi–Me (Mе = V, Mo, Bi) coordination spheres. Modeling EXAFS curve for Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalyst is presented in Fig. 9b (designated by pink color). Table S3 presents the list of interatomic distances and coordination numbers obtained during EXAFS curve modeling. To model the interatomic Bi–O distances, the scattering paths typical for α-Bi2O3 were used. Note that the first coordination sphere of Bi3+ ions in oxides are strongly disordered BiO5, BiO6 or (rarely) BiO7 polyhedrons [60,61]. The Bi–O distance in such polyhedrons varies in the range 2.08–2.80 Å. For a complete description of the local Bi environment, it was necessary to specify a set of bond lengths and correlated parameters. Two groups of Bi–O distances were used to describe the first coordination sphere of Bi within the Bi/Mo = 0.0075 sample: short (2.16 Å) and long (2.77 Å). The high value of the Debye parameter obtained by EXAFS modeling (Table S3) indicated the broad distribution of Bi–O bond lengths near preset values. This is typical for the local oxygen environment of Bi in oxide systems. The modeling of Bi–Mе (Mе = V, Mo, Bi) distances was performed taking into account the incorporation of Bi within the six-membered channel of M1 structure. The localization of Bi cations within such channels of the orthorhombic M1 phase was previously considered in the work of Ishikawa et al [48]. Since the structures of six-membered channels within M1 and M2 phases are similar, the obtained results do not rule out the possibility of incorporation of Bi within M2 particles. Due to the presence of a lone electron pair, the Bi3+ ion must be shifted toward the channel wall, similarly to the Te atom [8,62]. In such a case, the smallest Bi–Me distance is close to 3.2 Å, while other cations around Bi are located at distances of 3.5–3.7 Å (Fig. 10 ). This is the only opportunity to bind Bi with oxygen atoms from the channel wall to form the desired Bi–O length (in the range of 2.1–2.8 Å). Note that the Bi–Me distance, close to 3.2 Å, was possible to model in case of Me = V only, which indicates Bi localization near MeO6 octahedrons occupied predominantly by V. Also, the described model takes into account the Bi–O distance between Bi and axial oxygen from the VO6 octahedron (a length of 3.47 Å). Note that the Bi–V and Bi–Mo distances are not resolved as separate peaks on the FT curve due to the proximity of their values. However, attempts to describe the corresponding spectral peak using only one Bi–Me distance did not provide good agreement between the calculated and experimental curves. Also, the FT curve of the Bi/Mo = 0.0075 catalyst contained the additional peak simulated as the Bi–Bi distance of 4.11 Å. This corresponds to a typical M1 interlayer distance, indicating the formation of Bi–O–Bi chains along the c-axis. Therefore, XANES/EXAFS data indicate that Bi3+ ions in the composition of MoVNbTeO catalysts have a local structure differing from the Bi environment in bismuth oxide and/or bismuth molybdate. The obtained experimental EXAFS curve for the Bi-modified catalyst was fitted using a model that considered the position of Bi within six-membered channels of the M1/M2 structure. 4 Discussion In the present work it was shown that incorporation of Bi in the structure of MoVNbTe catalysts caused an increase in tolerance of the active surface toward severe conditions – enhanced temperature (up to 460 °C) and the reducing nature of the reaction mixture (C2H6/O2 = 3/1). Under such conditions, the unmodified catalyst was found to be significantly deactivated, with a decrease in ethylene yield by almost two times. In the case of Bi-modified catalysts (Bi/Mo = 0.0075÷0.025), the change in ethylene yield was no more than 24% (Fig. 1). Deactivation of MoVNbTeO catalysts in ODE is thought to be related to partial destruction of the active surface structure caused by reduction/removal of Te [18]. In the case of Bi-containing MoVNbTeO oxides, the amount of Te removed from the M1 structure during synthesis or after ODE catalytic testing was evidently less than for the unmodified catalyst [22,24]. NAP-XPS study showed that Bi-modified catalysts under C2H6 + O2 conditions were characterized by enhanced Te concentration at the surface while compared with unmodified MoVNbTeO oxide (Fig. 5). Under reducing conditions (T = 460 °C, C2H6/O2 ratio up to 10/1) the enhanced Te concentration was maintained at the surface/subsurface of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts in contrast to the unmodified sample. For the latter, the Te/(Mo + V) ratio was found to decrease from 0.23 to 0.16 when ethane concentration in the mixture was increased (Table S2). In accordance with obtained NAP-XPS data, the states of Mo and V were not changed under ODE conditions for all studied MoVNbTeO oxides (Fig. 4). Note that the increase in ethylene yield over Bi-modified catalysts is probably caused by the enhanced Te concentration on their surface (Fig. 1) due to direct participation of Te in the formation of active sites for selective alkane oxidation [15,63]. Also, obtained experimental data does not rule out the incorporation of some part of Bi atoms in active surface sites (ensembles) resulting in improvement of overall catalytic activity. Both M1 and M2 crystal structures are characterized by the presence of six- and seven-membered (for M1 only) channels extended along the [001] crystallographic direction [8,62]. Tellurium atoms within six-membered channels are characterized by 80% occupancy, while Te occupancy for seven-membered channels is no more than 20%. In the case of the M1 structure, Te atoms are located within distorted trigonal bipyramids TеO4Е (Е – lone pair of electrons) forming infinite –Tе–O–Tе–O– chains. Such chains are considered as oxygen reservoirs that are able to prevent the surface reduction/reconstruction [64]. However, the reduction of Te takes place under severe reaction conditions, followed by the release of Te from the M1 phase [20], accompanied by Te° sublimation and the partial destruction of the active surface structure. The loss of surface Te content can be compensated by diffusion from the subsurface/bulk zone of M1 particles along the channel direction caused by high Te mobility [21,39]. The gradual depletion of M1 particle bulk Te occurs during prolonged reaction exposure at high temperature (450–500 °C). NAP-XPS data presented in Fig. 5 shows that the modification of MoVNbTeO by Bi prevents the depletion of Te in catalyst particles under reducing conditions. The average XPS analysis depth of ˜1.5 nm corresponds not only to the surface, but also the subsurface zone. Obtained results indicate that the Bi modification influences the concentration and mobility of Te within MoVNbTeO particles. EXAFS spectroscopy revealed that the local environment of Bi within modified catalysts is different from that in α-Bi2O3 and α-Bi2Mo3O12. Corresponding EXAFS curves were well fitted using a model with Bi–O and Bi–Me distances typical for positions within six-membered channels of the M1 structure (Fig. 10). Note that localization of Bi within such channels was previously considered in the work of Ishikawa et al [22,48]. Therefore, Bi and Te occupy equivalent positions within the M1 structure. In accordance with in situ XRD data, it was established that modification of MoVNbTeO catalysts by Bi results in the increase in M1 destruction temperature under reducing conditions (Fig. 7). In the case of unmodified catalysts, the value of cell parameter c (Fig. 8) and also M1 crystal size (Fig. S7) were found to be decreased during the decomposition of the M1 structure. This is likely related to the removal of Te from the M1 phase accompanied by the compression of the crystal lattice along the c-axis as result of escape from extended channels. In the case of Bi-modified catalysts, the c parameter was not substantially changed even under strongly reducing conditions – above 500 °C in 8% C2H6/He flow (Fig. 7). The Bi3+ species mixed with Te cations within six-membered channels provide a limitation of Te mobility, preventing Te release from the M1 phase. This influences the surface/subsurface Te concentration and also the structure and number of active sites for the ODE process. The redox potential for the Te4+/Te° pair is higher than for the Bi3+/Bi° pair [65]. In other words, the reduction of Bi3+ ions is evidently more difficult from a thermodynamic point of view than is the reduction of Te4+. So, the average strength of the Bi3+–O bond is greater in comparison to the Te4+–O bond. The presence of Bi in the M–O–M–O–M (M = Bi, Te) chains within M1 channels (especially the near-surface region) prevents the removal of oxygen from such chains, resulting in the preservation of the oxidation state of Te. The role of Bi in the enhancement of M1 phase tolerance toward reducing reaction conditions is also related to the prevention of deep Te reduction accompanied by the preservation of the active site structure at the surface of the MoVNbTeO particles. The increased Te concentration at the surface of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts can be related to the appearance of 25–30 wt % M2 phase. The migration of Te from the M2 structure to the M1 phase has been discussed as a way to balance its losses under reaction conditions [2], suggesting that the improved stability of the M1 phase may be caused by the presence of M2 phase in sufficient quantity. However, no stabilization was observed during heating in 8% C2H6/He flow for the unmodified catalyst containing ˜20 wt % of M2 phase (Fig. S5). Note that in the present work the incorporation of Bi within extended six-membered channels of the M2 structure is not ruled out. The same effect of Bi on Te mobility should be expected for M1 and M2 structures due to the identity of the six-membered channels in such phases. The incorporation of Bi in the M2 structure must cause the limitation of Te migration into the M1 phase. It is well known that M1-based catalysts have the ability of C–H activation, in contrast to pure M2 phase [10,24]. The deactivation in ODE is also related to the destruction of the active surface structure of M1 particles. Therefore, based on literature and experimental data it can be concluded that the enhanced tolerance of Bi-containing MoVNbTeO catalysts toward reducing reaction conditions is caused mainly by the modification of the M1 phase. 5 Conclusions The modification of a MoVNbTeO catalyst by Bi was performed with the aim of improving tolerance toward strongly reducing conditions in the oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane. The Bi was introduced during the solution mixing procedure as a part of the slurry method. The catalysts modified by Bi exhibited enhanced tolerance to deactivation in comparison to unmodified MoVNbTeO oxide. The state and composition of the catalyst surface were analyzed using NAP-XPS immediately under C2H6 + O2 conditions, with variation of the reaction temperature and C2H6/O2 ratio. Increased Te content in the surface/subsurface region was found under reaction conditions for Bi-modified catalysts, in contrast to the unmodified sample. EXAFS spectroscopy revealed that the local environment of Bi within MoVNbTeO particles differed from those in bismuth oxide or bismuth molybdate. It corresponded to positions within extended six-membered channels of the M1 structure, which are similar to Te sites. Incorporation of Bi caused the limitation of Te mobility within channels, preventing its reduction under severe reaction conditions and resulting in a significant decrease in the degree of deactivation for Bi-modified ODE catalysts at high temperature and in the mixture with high ethane concentration (C2H6/O2 >1). The increase in the temperature of M1 phase destruction in ethane flow for Bi-modified catalysts was revealed using in situ XRD. The crystal lattice of the modified M1 phase did not undergo compression along the c-axis during heating in C2H6/He flow, in contrast to the unmodified catalyst, indicating the influence of Bi on Te mobility within the extended channels of the M1 structure. Modification with Bi is the excellent example of how to improve the catalytic properties of MoVNbTeO mixed oxides as industrially relevant catalysts for ODE, with the aim of further commercialization. coredata.dc:description: This work presents the investigation of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane (ODE) using the combination of NAP-XPS, in situ XRD and XANES/EXAFS techniques. It was found that introduction of Bi improves the tolerance of catalysts toward severe reaction conditions (high temperature and/or enhanced ethane/oxygen ratio) resulting in a significant decrease in the degree of deactivation. In accordance with NAP-XPS data, the surface/subsurface Te concentration was maintained for Bi-containing MoVNbTeO catalysts even after treatment with a reducing reaction mixture (C2H6/O2 >3) at temperatures up to 460 °C. In the case of the unmodified catalyst, such treatment resulted in the surface/subsurface depletion of Te due to the reduction into the Te° state followed by its sublimation into the gas phase. The incorporation of Bi within extended six-membered channels of the M1 structure was suggested based on XANES/EXAFS data. Such incorporation probably influences the mobility of Te within channels, resulting in the limitation of Te diffusion from the particle bulk to the surface. The improved tolerance of catalytically active M1 phase toward severe reaction conditions was confirmed by in situ XRD data during heating in a mixture of 8 wt % C2H6/He.
coredata.dc:title: NAP-XPS and in situ XRD study of the stability of Bi-modified MoVNbTeO catalysts for oxidative dehydrogenation of ethane
